candidates.name: Cold start time
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : 5-10ms (vs 100-500ms for containers, 3-30s for VMs)

candidates.name: Memory overhead
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : ~3MB per isolate (vs ~50MB for containers, ~512MB+ for VMs)

candidates.name: Isolation level
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Memory-isolated but shares kernel and engine

candidates.name: Language support
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : JavaScript/WebAssembly only

candidates.name: Use case sweet spot
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : High-concurrency, short-lived computations

candidates.name: Edge Computing Products
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : If your app processes user requests at the network edge, isolates can handle JavaScript execution without spinning up full VMs. Cloudflare Workers uses this to run code globally with minimal overhead.

candidates.name: Microservices Architectures
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : For services that need rapid scaling, isolates provide isolation without the weight of containers. This reduces cold-start times from seconds to milliseconds.

candidates.name: Modularize Code
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Break features into isolated modules that can run in separate V8 contexts. This mirrors microservices but at a finer grain, improving fault tolerance.

candidates.name: Resource Management
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Allocate CPU and memory per isolate, ensuring fair sharing. Tools like Deno or Node.js with worker threads can prototype this.

candidates.name: Security by Design
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Isolates provide sandboxing, reducing attack surfaces. Integrate this early to avoid retrofitting security later.

candidates.name: Hybrid Stacks
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Deploy isolates within containers for portability, or use VMs to manage isolate pools. Kubernetes can orchestrate this, with isolates as pods for fine-grained scaling.

candidates.name: Monitoring and Metrics
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : From day one, instrument for isolate-specific metrics like heap usage or execution time. Tools like Prometheus can track these, ensuring efficiency goals are met.

candidates.name: Structured logging
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Log everything meaningful with context

candidates.name: Local development
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Use Wrangler (Cloudflare) or Deno CLI to run isolates locally before deploying

candidates.name: Distributed tracing
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Implement trace IDs across requests

candidates.name: Compile to WebAssembly
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Port critical algorithms to Rust/C++ and compile to Wasm

candidates.name: Hybrid architecture
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Use isolates for API layer, call out to specialized services for heavy compute

candidates.name: Evaluate Deno
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Supports TypeScript natively and has better tooling for mixed workloads

candidates.name: Durable Objects
candidates.acceptedAnswer: (Cloudflare): Stateful isolates for persistent connections

candidates.name: External state
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Store in Redis, KV stores, or databasesâ€”treat isolates as pure functions

candidates.name: Session persistence
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Use cookies or JWTs for user state across isolate invocations

candidates.name: Keep bundles small
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Under 1MB compressed. Use dynamic imports for optional features

candidates.name: Warm-up strategies
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Send synthetic requests during deploys to pre-warm isolates

candidates.name: Accept trade-offs
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : 50ms cold start is still 10x faster than containers

candidates.name: Use Web Standards
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Stick to standard Fetch API, Request/Response objects, Web Crypto

candidates.name: Abstraction layer
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Wrap platform-specific features

candidates.name: Multi-cloud deployment
candidates.acceptedAnswer: : Run same code on multiple platforms for redundancy
